title: Your Purpose Statement
description: Pull together what you've learned about your values into a single, personal purpose statement. This isn't about finding the 'right' answer — it's about drafting a first version that feels true.

steps.title: One Sentence That Changes Everything
steps.content: Imagine you had a personal compass — one sentence that could guide your decisions when life gets noisy. Not a corporate mission statement, not an inspirational quote from someone else. Just a clear, honest line about what you're here to do. Today, you're going to write your first draft of that sentence.

steps.title: Purpose Is a Draft, Not a Decree
steps.content: A lot of people freeze when they hear the word 'purpose' because it sounds permanent and grand. But your purpose statement is just a working draft — a snapshot of what matters to you right now. It will evolve as you do, and that's the point. A good purpose statement usually touches on two things: what you value most, and how you want to show up in the world. It doesn't need to be poetic. It needs to be honest. Think of it as a personal north star — close enough to guide you, far enough away to keep pulling you forward.
steps.keyTakeaway: Your purpose statement is a living draft that captures what matters to you and how you want to show up.

steps.title: Draft Your Purpose Statement
steps.content: Use the prompts below to warm up, then write one sentence that captures your sense of purpose. Don't overthink it — you can always revise later. A helpful formula: 'I want to live a life where I [value/quality] by [how you show up].' For example: 'I want to live a life where I keep growing and help others feel seen.' or 'I want to live a life grounded in curiosity, kindness, and creative energy.'
steps.exercisePrompt: First, answer the warm-up questions. Then write your one-sentence purpose statement.

exerciseItems.label: What do you want more of in your life?
How do you want people to experience you?
What would you do even if nobody noticed?

steps.title: Sit With It
steps.content: Read your purpose statement slowly. Let it land. It doesn't have to feel perfect — it just has to feel close.

reflectPrompts.prompt: How much does this statement resonate with you right now?
Is there anything important that feels missing from it?
What emotion comes up when you read it?

steps.title: Carry It With You
steps.content: Your purpose statement is a seed. Water it by keeping it visible and letting it inform one small decision today.
steps.commitPrompt: Today, I'll keep my purpose statement close by...
commitOptions: Writing it on a sticky note and putting it where I'll see it
Setting it as a reminder on my phone for tomorrow morning
Sharing it with someone I trust and asking what they think
